subject: Re: [junit] mocking 3rd party classes?
msgSnippet: ... If you have access to /good/ documentation that /clearly/ describes the behavior behind their API, then you can try simulating it and see how it goes. An
messageBody:
ferrismatic wrote:
>
>
> Hello:
>
> I have a situation where I need a mock object for a vendor provided
> class. I connect to a data provider via an IP address. They have
> provided an API which I implement, and get callbacks from them with
> the data. I can create a mock of one of their classes - but since
> it's not hooked up to their IP, there's no data in it.
>
> I suppose I could decompile their class and put some data in it - but
> at that point, am I really testing my interaction with their classes -
> or with one of my own munging?
>
> Thanks for any suggestions.

If you have access to /good/ documentation that /clearly/ describes the
behavior behind their API, then you can try simulating it and see how it
goes.

An alternative is to write simple Learning Tests against their (live)
API, then use that information to program your mocks.

It might be worth mocking one level further up, abstraction-wise. Then
you can test-drive an implementation of your own API that hides all the
complicated callback stuff, that connects to a live one of whatever they
have, but not have to test your business logic against their
infrastructure component. Without more specific information, I can't
make a clearer suggestion. :)

Good luck.
